newsitem.title: USA: US House committee backs oil reserve through Sep97.
newsitem.headline: US House committee backs oil reserve through Sep97.

text.p: The U.S. House Commerce Committee on Wednesday voted to extend through September 1997 the president's authority to draw down oil from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve in an energy emergency.
The measure, extending provisions of the Energy Policy and Conservation Act (EPCA) governing the government's oil stockpile, included no new terms for using the reserve.

Republican Rep. Dan Schaefer of Colorado, who has opposed the recent sales of oil from the SPR to help balance the budget, said authority for the reserve should be extended one year at a time until Congress reviews its oil sale policy.

If the money-raising oil sales become habitual, "we should pass shorter term EPCA extensions until we come up with a new comprehensive plan to address energy security issues," Schaefer said at the Commerce Committee meeting.
The SPR provisions must be reauthorizee by the Full House and Senate before Congress closes its session at the end of this month, because the current law expires September 30.

"While an energy emergency which would require the Reserve to be drawn down (while Congress is adjourned) is unlikely, it is not impossible," Schaefer warned, pointing to the terrorist attack on U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia and tension in Iraq.
